content:
I am a third-year graduate student in the Goldsmith Computational Modeling Laboratory at the University of Michigan. My research centers on using computational catalysis and machine learning for environmental sciences, specifically water remediation. I am also a 2018–2019 Fellow of the Michigan Institute for Computational Discovery and Engineering and a member of the Michigan Catalysis Science and Technology Institute.
I completed my B.S. in Chemical Engineering at Cornell University (2016), where I worked for the John Marohn Group in analytical chemistry. Before coming to University of Michigan, I served for two years as a logistics and product engineer for the U.S. Army Combat Capabilities Development Command Chemical Biological Center.
In my free time, I enjoy swimming, music composition, and organ performance.
 Check out my CV!

summary: Electrocatalysis is a promising approach to remediating nitrate-contaminated water
title: Electrocatalytic Nitrate Reduction
Machine Learning for Alloy Catalyst Discovery

content:
Aqueous nitrate (NO3–) ions are one of the world’s most widespread water pollutants, and present significant health and environmental concerns. Remediation approaches such as bacterial consumption (i.e., biological nitrate reduction) and ion-exchange (i.e., physical separation) are widespread and scalable, but have significant drawbacks. For example, biological reduction is infeasible for wastewater streams containing heavy metals, as these can poison the bacteria, and physical separation methods produce a concentrated nitrate brine stream which must then be stored or processed.
Electrocatalytic nitrate reduction (NO3RR)
summary: Alloying Pt and Ru can increase the activity and selectivity of transition metal electrocatalysts.
title: PtRu Alloys as Active Nitrate Reduction Electrocatalysts

summary: Metal sulfides may provide high activity without poisoning effects.
title: Rhodium Sulfides for Nitrate Reduction
